hints_html:
The two particular solutions from part (a) (each was formed using a pair of eigenvalue and eigenvector of A), i.e. \(\mathbf{y}_1, \mathbf{y}_2\) come in complex conjugate pairs too. That means they satisfy \(\mathbf{y}_2 = \bar{\mathbf{y}_1}\).

Now, the general complex-valued solution from part (a) is a linear combination of these with arbitrary complex constants \(C_1, C_2 ~\). What form of such constants, then, \(C_1, C_2 ~\) must we choose so that when placed in front of \(\mathbf{y}_1\) and \(\mathbf{y}_2\), we can obtain a real-valued solution?

You might need to concentrate on the follow fact for complex numbers:

\[\begin{aligned} z + \bar{z} = 2 \mathrm{Re}[z]\end{aligned}\]

is always a real number for any complex number z.

Think about how \(C_1,C_2 ~\) should be related to each other.

question: B 05 (b)
sols_html:
Continuing from the hint, to choose real-valued solutions, we choose \(C_2 = \bar{C_1}\), so that the general solution becomes:

\[\begin{aligned} \mathbf{y} = C_1 \mathbf{y_1} + C_2 \mathbf{y_2} = C_1 \mathbf{y_1} + \overline{C_1 \mathbf{y_1}} = 2 \mathrm{Re}\left[ C_1 \mathbf{y_1} \right]\end{aligned}\]

Recall that

\[\begin{aligned} \mathbf{y_1} = \mathbf{k_1} \exp{\lambda_1 t} = \left[ \begin{array}{c} 2+3i \\ 1 \end{array} \right] \exp{(1+2i)t}\end{aligned}\]

Since

\[\begin{aligned} \mathrm{Re} \left[ \mathbf{y_1} \right] = \left[ \begin{array}{c} 2 \\ 1 \end{array} \right] e^t \cos{2t} + \left[ \begin{array}{c} -3 \\ 0 \end{array} \right] e^t \sin{2t}\end{aligned}\]

\[\begin{aligned} \mathrm{Im} \left[ \mathbf{y_1} \right] = \left[ \begin{array}{c} 3 \\ 0 \end{array} \right] e^t \cos{2t} + \left[ \begin{array}{c} 2 \\ 1 \end{array} \right] e^t \sin{2t}\end{aligned}\]

The general form of real-valued solutions is:

\[\begin{aligned} \mathbf{y} &= D_1 \mathrm{Re} \left[ \mathbf{y_1} \right] + D_2 \mathrm{Im} \left[ \mathbf{y_1} \right] \\ &= D_1 \left( \left[ \begin{array}{c} 2 \\ 1 \end{array} \right] e^t \cos{2t} + \left[ \begin{array}{c} -3 \\ 0 \end{array} \right] e^t \sin{2t} \right)\\ &+ D_2 \left( \left[ \begin{array}{c} 3 \\ 0 \end{array} \right] e^t \cos{2t} + \left[ \begin{array}{c} 2 \\ 1 \end{array} \right] e^t \sin{2t} \right)\end{aligned}\]

where \(D_1\) and \(D_2\) are real constants.

Their relationship with the previous constants are \(D_1 = 2 \mathrm{Re} \left[ C_1 \right]\) and \(D_2 = -2 \mathrm{Im} \left[ C_1 \right] = e^t\)

Now if we impose the initial condition \(\mathbf{y}(0) = \left[ \begin{array}{c} 1 \\ 0 \end{array} \right]\), we get

\[\begin{aligned} D_1 \left[ \begin{array}{c} 2 \\ 1 \end{array} \right] + D_2 \left[ \begin{array}{c} 3 \\ 0 \end{array} \right] = \left[ \begin{array}{c} 1 \\ 0 \end{array} \right]\end{aligned}\]

Thus, \(D_1 = 0 ~\) and \(D_2 = \frac{1}{3}\), and the solution of the initial value problem is

\[\begin{aligned} \frac{1}{3} \left( \left[ \begin{array}{c} 3 \\ 0 \end{array} \right] e^t \cos{2t} + \left[ \begin{array}{c} 2 \\ 1 \end{array} \right] e^t \sin{2t} \right) = \frac{e^t}{3} \left[ \begin{array}{c} 3 \cos{2t} + 2 \sin{2t} \\ \sin{2t} \end{array} \right]\end{aligned}\]

Alternatively, one can solve directly from

\[\begin{aligned} \mathbf{y} = 2 \mathrm{Re}\left[ C_1 \mathbf{y_1} \right]\end{aligned}\]

And impose the initial condition \(\mathbf{y}_0 = \left[ \begin{array}{c} 1 \\ 0 \end{array} \right]\) direcly to find that \(C_1 = -\frac{i}{6}\).

Then compute the real part to get the same result as above. The amount of algebra involved will be slightly less.

statement_html:
Consider the differential equation system

\[\begin{aligned} \mathbf{y}' = A\mathbf{y} ~\end{aligned}\]

where A has an eigenvalue \(\lambda_1 = 1 + 2i\) with corresponding eigenvector

\[\begin{aligned} \mathbf{k}_{1}=\left[ \begin{array}{c} 2+3i\\ 1 \end{array} \right]\end{aligned}\]

Recall that for real matrices, eigenvalues and eigenvectors come in complex conjugate pairs.

Find the real form (no imaginary terms) of the solution that satisfies initial conditions \(\mathbf{y}(0)=\left[ \begin{array}{c} 1\\ 0 \end{array} \right]\)
